dc:description:
The relationship between MT-TK and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of May 17, 2021. The MT-TK gene encodes the mitochondrial transfer RNA (tRNA) for lysine. Defects of this tRNA lead to impaired mitochondrial translation, which leads to decreased synthesis of mtDNA-encoded subunits of oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) complexes I, III, IV, and V and thus impaired OXPHOS enzyme activities.

The MT-TK gene was first reported in relation to maternally inherited Leigh syndrome spectrum in 1993 (PMID: 8170567). Of note, variants (particularly m.8344A>G) in MT-TK are more commonly associated with other mitochondrial disease clinical syndromes, especially MERRF (myoclonus epilepsy, ragged red fibers). Evidence supporting the gene-disease relationship between MT-TK and Leigh syndrome spectrum includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included 2 variants in 15 cases (11 with m.8344A>G and 4 with m.8363G>A) from 13 publications (PMIDs: 24374964, 18319067, 10868777, 22981260, 18176892, 8602753, 33718511, 9851442, 30271374, 11108511, 8170567, 8133313, 12661941). Of note, while Gene Curation SOP Version 8 maxes case level missense variant total score at 7, the Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel agreed the maximum score would be 12 given that the majority of pathogenic mitochondrial DNA variants are missense variants (the total score for genetic level evidence in this curation was 11). Segregation information is scored as case level evidence according to the criteria established by the Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel. Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by known biochemical function and functional alteration in non-patient cells (PMIDs: 27977873, 7739567, 22354625). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support this gene-disease relationship, including that more than three years have elapsed from the first proposal of the association. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on May 17, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed 82% heteroplasmy in blood, 86% in muscle. There was no maternal sample but the brother showed 60% heteroplasmy in blood and 61% in muscle. Isolated mitochondria from muscle showed patient II-3 showed a near absence of complex V . activity and low complex I, III, and IV activities compared , to control values. SCORE: 1pt (0.5 recurrent, established variant, 0.5pt segregation of heteroplasmy)

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 11-3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband,  at 15 months, developed a progressive course of gait unsteadiness with falling, myoclonus of the trunk and limbs, and swallowing dysfunction. Partial complex seizures with secondary generalization developed around age 2 years and a moderate degree of global cognitive impairment was noted. 
Brain MRI at age 5 years showed bilateral increased T 2- weighted signal in the putamen; however, a follow-up MRI 14 months later showed resolution of the basal ganglia abnormalities and instead increased T,-weighted signal in the posterior medulla.
Elevated lactate levels (venous lactate, 50 mg/dL, cerebrospinal fluid lactate, 31.1 mg/dL).
Muscle biopsy: muscle histochemistry revealed diminished glycogen stores in some myofibers. Cytochrome c oxidase staining revealed nearly complete absence of cytoplasmic staining with scattered fibers containing a prominent subsarcolemmal crescent. No ragged red fibers were seen.
Family History: Brother with autism (proband in this case), half sister with generalized seizures and oppositional behavior at 9 years, normal MRI and lactate.

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed a high level of heteroplasmy (no further details), no maternal sample. SCORE: 0.5 pt (recurrent established variant)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report Pronicki 2007
evidence.detectionMethod: Screening for common mtDNA and SURF1 gene mutations was applied. Sequencing of part (nucleotides 1777-4218, 4850-9847, 14753-15399, 16515-1173) of the patient’s mitochondrial genome was performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband showed some developmental delay, at the age of 20 months his level of development was that of an 11-month old child.  At the age of 20 months he was admitted to the hospital due to loss of appetite, tachypnoea and worsening of general condition which developed during the treatment of rhinitis. Somnolence, loss of muscle tone and dehydration were observed. Examination revealed insufficient body mass, lowered muscle tone (the boy was not walking), thinning of the skin and increased perspiration. Emotional contact and comprehension were good but the boy was not talking.
Laboratory tests showed lactic acidaemia (40-82 mg/dl) and hyperalaninaemia (516 μmol/l; normal value 186-318 μmol/l). The proband died at 28 months.
No brain MRI, but post mortem neuropathological lesions were typical for LS.
"Fig4. Microscopic view of post mortem brain stem lesions typical for LS. Vascular proliferation, spongy degeneration, neuronal damage and small pseudocyst formation. Macroscopically the central nervous system showed symmetrical focal grey discolorations localized in the basal ganglia and pons, similar more distinctly outlined ones in the dorsal part of the medulla approximately 0.4 cm in diameter, and bilateral delicate discolorations in the vicinity of the dentate nuclei. Microscopically the above foci showed spongy degeneration, astroglial and capillary proliferation as well as neuronal damage. In several foci central microcystic areas had developed. "

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed 97% variant heteroplasmy in blood. SCORE: 0.5pt (recurrent , established variant)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Neurological phenotype: The patient presented at 10 years of age with a 3-year history of tremors and unsteady gait followed by progressive weakness and voice changes. At presentation she had a 2 week history of intractable hiccups, dysphagia, dyspnea, and difficulty managing salivary secretions. On exam she was cognitively intact with hypertelorism, frontal bossing, vertical ophthalmoplegia, generalized weakness (proximal greater than distal), athetoid movements of the fingers, areflexia, truncal ataxia, dysmetria, lower extremity atrophy, and ataxic gait.
Initial MRI: Symmetric T2 hyperintensities in medulla and pons. Repeat MRI: Progression of lesions in the tectum, oculomotor nuclei, and cerebral peduncles, pons, and superior cerebellar peduncles. 
Lactate: Lactate was elevated in both serum (1.5-7.8 mMol/L) and CSF (3.2 mMol/L).
Muscle biopsy: revealed type I fiber predominance with normal spectrophotometeric analysis.

evidence.dc:description: GnomAD: 0 homoplasmic individuals, 6 heteroplasmic individuals with a max heteroplasmy of 78%. Mixed in silico predictions: MitoTIP Possibly benign (11.3), PON-mt-tRNALikely neutral (0.422), HmtVarPathogenic (0.900). The proband showed >90% in all tissues examined including liver, kidney, skeletal muscle, fibroblast and nine regions of the brain. No maternal sample was available. SCORE: 0.5pt (recurrent established pathogenic variant).

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 14
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequencing of mtDNA and PDHC E l alpha cDNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Diagnosis of Leigh syndrome confirmed by neuropathology. The case had presented with developmental delay, hypotonia, ophthalmoplegia, optic atrophy, bulbar problems, respiratory disturbance, elevated lactate.
Family History: The maternal grandmother was diagnosed with myopathy at age 54 years

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed 97% heteroplasmy level in blood, the mother showed 80% heteroplasmy level in blood. SCORE: 1pt (0.5 established recurrent variant, 0.5 segregation of heteroplasmy)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case 3
evidence.detectionMethod: Familial targeted testing, no methodology given
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The patient presented at 17 months with acute ataxia and spells of head drops, eye flutters, tremulousness and falling in the setting of influenza A. She returned to the hospital 2 weeks later due to return of tremors and head drops after interval improvement. Her exam revealed a left esotropia, mildly diffuse central hypotonia, tremor with central titubation, falling, and episodes of head drop with eye flutter that had positive correlation on EEG consistent with generalized seizures. She developed dysphagia followed by respiratory failure and required a tracheostomy, became ventilator dependent.
Elevated lactate and alanine: Lactate (Whole Blood): 3.0 (0.5–1.6 mmol/L) and Alanine (Plasma) 664.7 (89–440 umol/L)).
MRI: patchy and confluent, nearly symmetric T2 hyperintensity throughout the brainstem.

evidence.dc:description: The proband's blood sample showed m.8344A>G to be present at 96% heteroplasmy. The proband's sister and mother were asymptomatic and showed heteroplasmy of 80% and 70% in the blood. SCORE: 1pt (0.5pt recurrent established variant, 0.5pt segregation of heteroplasmy)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report: Buda 2013
evidence.detectionMethod: The SURF1, MTATP6 and MTTK genes
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband showed normal development but with dyslexia and school difficulties from an early age.
Onset was at 13 years in the form of 'drop atacks' and associated head injuries. Over the next five months he showed limb weakness, double vision, difficulties in swallowing, dyspnoea and stool incontinence appeared and rapidly developed over several weeks. Respiratory failure occurred and required artificial ventilation. Episodes of seizures, impaired consciousness, and difficulty in controlling blood pressure were observed.
Elevated lactate (24 mg/dl, ref. < 20 mg/dl) 
Liver enlargement (6 cm), mild transaminase elevation (< 100 U/l) and hyperammonaemia (300 μg/dl)
At 15 years diagnosed with severe bulbo-pyramidalsyndrome. Neurological progression recurred at the age of 15.5 years. 
At the age of 16.5, the boy experienced a stroke-like episode and died at age 17 years. 
The bilateral T2 thalamus, putamen, midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata lesions, and entire length of the spinal cord were involved (Fig 1).
Muscle biopsy: Histochemistry of muscle samples revealed few distinct ragged blue fibres (RBF) (Fig. 3) accompanied by a pattern suggestive of mosaic COX deficiency and mild to moderate lipid accumulation. No classical ragged red fibres (RRF) were observed. muscle homogenate showed an increased citric synthase activity, normal complex I-IV
No family history

evidence.dc:description: GnomAD: homoplasmic: 0/56434, heteroplasmic 1 individual with 54% heteroplasmy. Pathogenic in silico predictions; Mitotip: Likely pathogenic (19.2), PON-mt-tRNAPathogenic (0.868), HmtVarPathogenic (0.750). The proband showed high heteropaslmy levels in multiple tissues: skeletal muscle 80%, heart 89%, frontal cortex 87%, liver 97%. There was no maternal sample. Skeletal muscle sample showed decreased levels of complex I (5% of control) and IV (b10% of control) .The sample also revealed adiminished amount of complex V holoenzyme (35% of control). Complex I, IV and V activity was reduced in muscle, heart and frontal cortex. SCORE: 0.5 pts (established recurrent variant).

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 14
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband showed a failure to thrive and progressive hypotony developed beginning in infancy, and he was wheelchair-dependent from the age of 8 years. Psychological investigations revealed moderate mental retardation, which later became severe. At the age of 8 he had his first epileptic paroxysm, and at the age of 11, an acute stroke-like encephalopathy developed, resulting in generalized weakness and respiratory failure requiring ventilatory support.
MRI revealed bilateral necrotic basal ganglia lesions typical of Leigh syndrome.
Hyperlactacidemia (2.5–5.5 mmol/l, controls b2.1 mmol/l) with an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio (L/P 28).

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed 95% heteroplasmy in blood, 96% muscle (Quantitative pyrosequencing). Mother: 77% blood (short stature, high blood lactate levels, and epilepsy) Cousin: 87% blood (seizures from 8 years) Large pedigree, see figure 7 for additional assymptomatic carriers and heteroplasmy levels which segregate with disease. SCORE 1 pt (0.5 recurrent established variant, 0.5 segregation of heteroplasmy)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report: Shen 2018
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband is a 16-year-old boy with a family history of epilepsy who presented with acute respiratory failure, limb weakness, diabetes mellitus, sinus tachycardia, lactic acidosis, and pneumonia. He went on to develop cranial nerve palsy, myoclonus, generalized seizures, ataxia, recurrent pneumonia, and hypotension. He was diagnosed with both MERFF and Leigh syndrome. 
Elevated lactate 9.4 mmol/L, pyruvate, and glucose levels.
MRI: bilateral, symmetric, high-intensity T2-weighted signals in the thalamus, brainstem, and gray matter of the spinal cord. Serial MRI scans over time showed progressive changes (Fig 2, 3 and 4) After 7 months, T2-weighted MRI (Figure 4) revealed hyperintensities in the bilateral thalamus (arrow in Figure 4A), tegmental area of the midbrain (arrow in Figure 4B), pons (arrow in Figure 4C), medulla (arrow in Figure 4D), and the cervical and thoracic spinal cord (new lesions, hollow arrow in Figure 4E).
Histochemical analyses revealed ragged red fibers (RRF) and decreased cytochrome oxidase activity.

evidence.dc:description: The proband's blood sample was near homoplasmic for the variant, no maternal sample was available. SCORE: 0.5 (established recurrent variant).

evidence.rdfs:label: Case 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Details of methodology were not given.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband was reported to have a progressive neurological phenotype: The proband presented at 3 years with motor delays, sensorineural hearing loss, myoclonus, and lactic acidosis (4 millimolar) and was diagnosed with MERFF. At age 7 she  developed increasing tremors that impeded self-feeding. At age 8 years, she developed acute respiratory decompensation following 3 days of cough and rhinorrhea. She was admitted to an intensive care unit where she was found to be febrile. From 11 to 14 years, insidious decline in cranial nerve function was noted leading to ophthalmoparesis and weakness of the muscles of mastication. Her myoclonus became increasingly refractory with worsening of her EEG background. Mechanical ventilation intervention required at 8 years.
Brain MRI: Initial Mild T2 signal abnormalities of the insula;  at age 14 years (Figure 1) )  bilateral, symmetric T2-hyperintensities of the putamina, dorsomedial thalami, dentate nuclei, brainstem nuclei, peri-aqueductal gray matter, and central gray matter of the cervical and thoracic spinal cord. 
Serum lactate ranged from 5.7-7.0 millimolar.

evidence.dc:description: The variant was found to be homoplasmic in the proband's muscle, and 93% heteroplasmy in blood. SCORE: 0.5pt (0.5 established recurrent variant)

evidence.rdfs:label: Pedigree 10, proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband was initially diagnosed with MERFF but had neuropathological findings consistent with Leigh syndrome, maternal family history of mitochondrial disease

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed high heteroplasmy in multiple tissues: blood 81%; quadriceps muscle 99%; extraocular muscle 97%; cerebellum 97%; cerebral cortex 97%; cardiac muscle 97%; liver 99% and kidney 98% (Dot blot assay). The maternal blood sample showed 72% heteroplasmy. Mitochondria were isolated from PM tissue from heart, kidney and skeletal muscle. Enzyme activities showed a consistent decrease in complexes I and IV in all tissues examined (Table 1). This was most pronounced in heart where complex 1 activity was only 1-2% of control. Complex IV activities were reduced to approximately 50% of control values. SCORE: 1pt (0.5 recurrent established variant, 0.5 segregation of heteroplasmy levels)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report Sweeney 1994
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Neuropathological confirmation of Leigh syndrome. 
The proband had a progressive myoclonus and ataxia: At the age of 7 years he developed occasional myoclonic jerks affecting first the limbs and later the head. By the age of 10 years
the jerks had become more frequent but tended to occur in clusters separated by up to a week. He also had additional brief atonic seizures. Aged 17 his speech was slurred, his handwriting unintelligible. On examination at age 17 years he had a slurring dysarthria and normal hearing. Pursuit eye movements were jerky, with hypometric saccades in the vertical plane. There were occasional myoclonic jerks in the limbs, with mild upper limb ataxia. Power was normal. The tendon reflexes were brisk with ankle clonus and extensor plantar responses. Joint position and vibration sense were impaired in the toes. Romberg's sign was positive and his gait was broad based. Progression and severe disease were evident by 18 years, he developed dysphagia and pneumonia, requiring ventilation and nasogastric feeding.
Computerised tomography showed cerebellar atrophy.
Elevated lactate: Plasma and CSF lactate concentrations were 4.1 and 2.9 mmol/l (normal < 1.8). CSF protein was 0.27 g/I.
MRI scan showed marked atrophy of the posterior fossa structures, which was present in a milder degree in the cerebral hemispheres. A striking high signal lesion was seen to extend along the posterior surface of the brainstem from the level of the dorsal column nuclei to the midbrain.
A second MRI scan showed rostral extension, in continuity, of the high signal lesion which now involved the thalamus (Fig. 1).
Muscle biopsy: no Ragged red fibres, A high proportion of fibres showed very low or negligible cytochrome oxidase activity. Electron microscopy showed the presence of large intermyofibrillar neutral lipid droplets in about 15% of fibres. Occasional mitochondria lacked internal cristae.
Neuropath: see text for full notes; characteristic of subacute necrotizing encephalopathy (Leigh syndrome).

evidence.dc:description: The proband showed >98% heteroplasmy in skeletal muscle and blood (RFLP analysis), the mother, diagnosed with MERFF showed 84% in muscle and 72% in blood. 61% heteroplasmy in a maternal aunt and 59% in the maternal grandmother was found in blood samples. Muscle biopsy from the proband showed decreased activities of all respiratory-chain enzymes (Table 1) SCORE: 1pt (0.5pt established recurrent variant, 0.5pt segregation of heteroplasmy)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report Shtibans 1999
evidence.detectionMethod: mtDNA sequencing of ATP6/8 and the MT-tRNAs
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Failure to thrive was noted in the proband from 5 months and from 12 months regression of developmental milestones such as pulling to stand and sitting was noted. The child developed
generalized seizures and showed increasing respiratory distress. When last hospitalized at 27 months of age, she was unresponsive with fixed dilated pupils and minimal purposeful movements. Deep tendon reflexes were brisk with clonus in all limbs; plantar reflexes were extensor. She died shortly thereafter of cardiorespiratory failure.
Elevated lactate: lactic acid in venous blood ranged between 3.8 and 9.5 mmol/L (normal, less than 2.5 nunol/L). ragged red and cytochrome c oxidase-negative fibers.
Brain MRI: bilateral lucencies in the cerebral peduncles. 
Muscle biopsy from the proband showed decreased activities of all respiratory-chain enzymes (Table 1) and ragged red fibers 
Family History: Mother developed myoclonus epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF) in her late 20s. with ragged red and cytochrome c oxidase-negative fibers
A maternal half-sister of the proband had died at 2.5 years of age from neuropathologically proven Leigh syndrome. Pedigree shown in Figure 1.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: mtDNA A8344G and A3243G ruled out

evidence.dc:description: The proband's blood , skeletal muscle and liver tissues were homoplasmic for the variant. The variant was detected in the blood of multiple family members: 22 yr mother 40% blood (migraine headaches), 4 yr sister 30% (migraine headaches), 15 yr maternal uncle 30% (ADHD, ID), 17 yr maternal aunt 40% (partial epilepsy), 39 yr maternal grandmother 20% (migraine headaches), 65 yr maternal great grandmother 10% (migraine headaches). SCORE: 1pt (0.5 recurrent established variant, 0.5 segregation of heteroplasmy levels)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report: Tsao 2003
evidence.detectionMethod: Methodology not specified but the proband was screened for the mitochondrial variants : m.3243A>G, m.8993T>G and m.8344A>G
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband was hypotonic and developmentally delayed since birth. At age 20 months, an upper respiratory tract infection and status asthmaticus led to hospital admission. Acute respiratory failure requiring respiratory support, progressive decline in mental status soon developed.
Neurologic regression over 3 months led to loss of all of his motor skills and milestones. Progressive external ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, generalized muscle weakness, left ventricular hypertrophy, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, pancreatitis, gastroesophageal reflux, bilateral severe sensorineural deafness, The proband died at 23 months. 
Persistent lactic acidosis serum lactate up to 10.6 mmol/L; normal 0.5–2.2 mmol/L
MRI: symmetric hyperintense T2-weighted signals within the putamina, claustra, thalami, midbrain, and medulla; brain magnetic resonance spectroscopy also revealed a large amount of lactate within the putamina.
His liver and skeletal muscle biopsies revealed markedly increased lipid accumulation, some scattered cytochrome c oxidase–deficient muscle fibers but without ragged red fibers, and some enlarged mitochondria. liver and skeletal muscle respiratory chain complexes, skeletal muscle pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, liver pyruvate carboxylase, and pyruvate dehydrogenase complex were normal.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is 'almost' homoplasmic in the proband's blood (RFLP analysis). No maternal sample reported. SCORE: 0.5 pt (recurrent established variant)

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report Monden 2013
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Developmental milestones of the proband were normal until 1year of age, when he could walk on his own. At 2years, he developed astatic seizures well-controlled by valproic acid (VPA). At 3years,he de veloped cerebel lar ataxia with dysarthria and wide-based gait. At 4years,he presented with atypical absence and myoclonic seizures.  Initial diagnosis was MERRF. At 6 years he developed bacterial pneumonia with slight fever (from 98 to 100 F) for 10 days. He did not have any neurological disturbance at that time. However, he suddenly presented with progressive bulbar palsy and marked generalized hypotonia two days after the body temperature was elevated above102F.
Brain T2-weighted MRI showed high-signal bilateral lesions from the pons to the medulla. lesions extending to the thalamus and bilateral cerebral hemispheres were noted on MRI (Fig. 3 (A)–(C) )4–6 weeks after the initial episode.
Lactate and pyruvate levels in serum elevated 33.2mg /dl and 1.89 mg/d l,respect ively. (CSF lactate and pyruvate levels were 22.3 mg/ dl and 1.33 mg/dl,respectively

evidence.dc:description: Paraffin embedded DNA extracted from the proband's brain indicated 92% heteroplasmy. Samples from other family members were not available. SCORE: 0.5 pt (recurrent , established variant)

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 111- 1
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from paraffin embedded tissue, MT-TK, MT-TL and ATP6, 8 were sequenced only.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Diagnosis of Leigh syndrome confirmed by neuropathology. The proband showed an infantile onset of mild spastic diparesis, clumsiness, pes caws deformities, and mental retardation. She was hospitalized because of pneumonia at the age of 12 years and died two months late after a cardiac arrest. Examination revealed bilateral papilledema, mild right facial weakness, nystagmus on lateral gaze, appendicular ataxia with reduced vibratory sensation, hypertonia, absent tendon reflexes, and bilateral Babinski signs.
Elevated lactate: (3.9 and 5.4 mM/L; normal, c2.2 mM/L
An autopsy documented the typical lesions seen in LS. 
Family History: multiple relatives of the proband showed a neurological disorder, see pedigree

evidence.dc:description: Scored default for a cybrid line with evidence of reduced oxygen consumption and reduced levels of tranlation of mitochondrial encoded genes including tRNAlys.

Fibroblasts from patient 1 (mt.8344A>G) and patient 2 (mt8356T>C) were enucleated, and the resulting cytoplasts were fused with an excess of cells from human r0 cell line 143B206. Cybrids with either 0% or 100% variant load were used in analysis. 
Fig1. oxygen consumption were decreased approximately 10-fold in cybrids harboring 100% of either the MERRF-8344 or the MERRF-8356 point mutation (N=4) compare to WT. Cytochemical staining for succinate dehydrogenase activity showed no differences among the cell lines examined, cytochemical staining for COX activity showed a marked decrease in the intensity of the reaction product in mutant cybrids compared with the wildtype cybrids. 
Fig 2. Analysis of mitochondrial translation using 35Smet incorporation (cytoplasmic synthesis inhibited by emetine). On average protein synthesis was decreased by 30% in both cybrids harboring both variants but the levels of individual proteins varied. The differences did not correlate with lysine content of proteins: ND4L contains no lysine but showed a 36% reduction in labelling compared to WT in mt.8344A>G cybrids. the accoumulaion of abberant protein in both cell line types was also noted. 
Northern blot analysis showed MERRF-8344 cybrids did exhibit a decrease (approximately 40%) in the steady-state levels of tRNALys, however the authors indicate that this would not be a significant change in level. No significant difference in steady state levels was observed with the MERRF-8356 variant.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cybrid study: mt.8344A>G

evidence.dc:description: Scored default for mitochondrial dysfunction: reduced ETC protein levels, reduced ATP production, reduced CoQ, increased ROS, increased autophagy. Altered morphology of mitochondrial.

Cybrid clones were prepared by fusing enucleated fibroblasts from patients or controls with 143B osteosarcoma cells, which lack mitochondrial DNA (rho 0 cells). Cybrid cell lines harbouring m.8344G (99% heteroplasmy) were selected for analysis and compare with a control cybrid clone (no further details given for the control). 
Fig 8: The amount of CoQ and ATP were 54% and 62% lower, respectively in the MERRF cybrid clone than in the control cybrid clone, cell proliferation was also significantly reduced, mitochondrial ROS production (8x) and the number of lysosomes (2x), were increased. 
Fig 9. expression levels of complexes II, III, and IV were reduced by 3.5-, 2.2-, and 1.3-fold, respectively, in MERRF cybrids
Fig 10. Immunohistochemistry showed many small, fragmented mitochondria that colocalized with LC3 (a marker of autophagy)
All the cell phenotypes were rescued by CoQ supplementation. Similar results were seen in the MERFF fibroblast line from which the cybrid lines were derived, 57% heteroplasmy.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cybrid study: m.8344A>G (2)

evidence.dc:description: per rubric: More than 10 gene with a related function

Rahman et al. reviews all genes associated with Leigh syndrome in Leigh Map 2017 (PMID: 27977873). These genes included at least thirteen nuclear genes directly involved in mitochondrial translation as well as five additional mt-tRNA genes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Review: LeighMap
